38616980.review: We know the devil can only be explainaed as an extraordinary visual novel. It takes three school ages students and throws them into a forest setting where they are forced to deal with problems they are avoiding. This VN is showing these students what they have to deal with for example being gay or being trans. It's very good at handling how people love the same gender and how someone can experience dysphoria without going into textbook definitions and making the game boring. Brilliant story, brilliant visuals and amazing music and sound. 100% recommend <3

38601722.review:
It's been a year since I first discovered this visual novel. Sometimes I'll find myself thinking about it. There's something about it that makes me keep coming back to it. It's not a very long visual novel, nor is it meaningful to me. The religious and LGBT undertones completely flew over my head. 

The thing is, you'll realize there are undertones. Maybe you'll be like me, and they'll fly over your head and leave you thinking about it for months. Maybe you'll have an instant epiphany your first run through like so many people on somethingawful did. Either way, you'll remember this story in all its complexity.

Presentation-wise, it's very good. The music combined with the art makes for a haunting presentation. The dialogue is written like a transcript of a conversation rather than a carefully-checked grammatically correct passage. And just as the store page says, someone always gets left out.

I still have confused feelings about this visual novel, and I probably will for years to come. But it's short and it's worth a read.

38360664.review: Beautiful and complex. This story makes you realize the importance of unity in adversary. Set to a chilling and melancholic background of washed out pictures of the forest and heart-pounding music, We Know the Devil leaves you with many questions, much to interperate, and a feeling of wanting more after every ending.

37751116.review:
Short, but gorgeous. The combination of the disposable camera photo backgrounds, the creepy-cool synth soundtrack, and sometimes vague writing makes this game at once highly eerie and heartfelt.

Also, it made my queer ass cry.

37565871.review:
this is a game that will make you think and question.
if you already question, this is a game that will make you think harder.
this is a game that will make you hurt.
if you already hurt, this is a game that will make you hurt deeply.
i just finished and i am currently crying and wondering what the point of anything is. i would recommend this game to anyone.

i am often disappointed with the experience of visual novels.
this one was short enough to keep me engaged the whole way and poignant enough to make me want more.
the writing is vague and suggestive. you'll be filling in gaps from your imagination and experience. but it is vivid enough to bring those ideas out of you.

i need a 15 hour nap and a hug

37112849.review:
A short but interesting visual novel. The unique art style helps futher the mysterious atmosphere of the setting. The game deals with teenage confusion over sexuality, gender, and social normals but in a borderline horror/supernatural manner. 

Overall, I'd recommend this game, especially on a sale! Just don't come expecting long length or a story that wraps up with a bow. Each ending leaves you to think about and interpret for yourself to some degree.

36641058.review: Someond did this on purpose. And it was good.

39505151.review:
I bought this game, as i do most of my games, on sale for only a few bucks. It is very short so i understand not wanting to pay full price. 

However, this game was an amazing experience and every route left me just a little bit more in love with it. The symbolism, the use of language, and the themes of acceptance and love were beautiful. I fully admit to marathoning this game to get all of the endings (Two blind playthroughs [red + true ending] and then guides to figure out how to get the others and then another true ending). Replaying it was like re-reading an old favorite and finding new details that you missed before.

So, my take is if you can get it on sale: DO IT. If not, either wait for one or just buy it if you don't mind spending ten bucks.

(P.S.: is there a fuck yes option for recommending a game? Cause if so I NEED IT FOR THIS.)

40961372.review:
I really wanted to like We Know the Devil. In fact, I loved the overall atmosphere and aesthetic, and the concept itself was right up my alley. But, unfortunately, this VN has a tragic flaw, and that's the writing.

For starters, I want to say that I love experimental fiction. But [i]this[/i]? Oh, boy, where do I even begin? Even though I was able to follow the story, there were times it felt jarring or needlessly cryptic, like it was intentionally trying to alienate its audience. Not to mention, there were several typos and words left out, which just added to my overall frustration with the prose. 

I did appreciate that each character had their own distinct voice and backstory, but no matter which route I seemed to take (even the "true ending"), it always seemed like one of the characters didn't get as much attention and was literally just a third wheel, which ticked me off considering the overall theme of the game is "try to keep the three together."

There was some great potential here, and I thoroughly enjoyed the build-up, but in the end, it was unsatisfying. The shortness of the game doesn't even bother me as much as the lack of clarity during certain scenes and the horribly unrefined prose. As an experience, yeah, it's aight, but, boy, is it underwhelming. I do appreciate the subject matter quite a bit, I just wish this game had taken some time to "breathe" a little to properly flesh out the characters and really immerse us into this world where god speaks through radios and bad kids meet the devil at a Christian summer camp.

40055272.review:
[i]We[/i] know the devil.  When I say we, I mean, [i]everyone[/i].
The devil doesn't just take on a form of a naked, balding red man holding a stupid cartoon pitchfork.
They take on a form that is untangible, abstrat, and far more horrifying.

We Know the Devil is a short visual novel telling the story of three "bad" teenagers at a summer camp to fight the devil.  A single playthrough of the game takes approximately an hour?  But you will want to explore the other two endings, + the "true ending", so perhaps a full playthrough should take approximately 2 hours.  Getting each of the endings + the true ending is pretty self-explanatory, but if you can't figure it out, you can just google how to get it, it's not a big deal.

I want to avoid spolilers, as it's a short game, it'd be harmful to the experience of playing it if too much is revealed.  What I can say though, WKtD does a good job of replicating the feeling of "third-wheeling".  From my experience, what usually seems to happen in groups of three is that two of the particpating people will just be closer together, leaving one person on the sideline, watching.  It's happened to all of us, and it feels isolating.  You want to just leave and go home, and let the other two enjoy themselves.  More than that even, you begin to feel like a nuisance, like your existence, at that moment, is detrimental to the other two's lives.

It sucks.

The game does a good job getting this feeling across.  
Other than that, the only thing I can think to add is that the game has a problem with loading/saving states of the game. Whenever I loaded up a save state, I was unable to create a save state again unless I restarted the game.  The game auto saves, but a couple times when I loaded up an autosave from the main menu, it would take me to a black screen where I wouldn't be able to do anything. The game is so short however that even if you did forget to save your progress, you can use the fastforward feature to get back to the point you were at in about a minute or two.

39951701.review:
Just blasted through this, would have taken less time but I spent some looking up how to get the fourth ending.  

There are only two serious criticisms worth noting.

1.  Needs editing.

2.  Too short, which is almost a recomendation in and of itself.  (The food is terrible and the portions are TOO SMALL!)

More time for character development would have amplified an already intense experience.  On the otherhand a short and sweet story completely avoids the heavy handed blungeoning similar attempts deliver.  Venus, Jupiter, and Neptune are also relatively relatable even if you're not LGBTQ because they're just kids who want to be themselves.  Adding more could actually spoil the magic.  

Also adored the soundtrack, though a longer story may have fitted it better as it comes off over the top in such a short time span, so I guess I'm conflicted.  Not conflicted about recommending this VN even a little bit, so much love put into it.

39711795.review: This game good and it'll make you cry. It's gay.

39629885.review: 青春期少女的心灵救赎之旅

39572136.review:
This is an emotional game, so I would recommend staying away from it until you are ready to tackle it. Personally, I found the story very relatable, which is probably why it hit me so hard. The struggles of being a closeted or self-denying trans/gay person are explored with beautiful art and a unique soundtrack. Even if you don't identify with the LGBTQ+ community, I think there is something strong for everyone in this game. 

To sum things up, this visual novel has done to me what most movies and books can't: it made me cry. It is a truly powerful game. Worth the buy, especially if on sale.

39538942.review: An amazing game on the damage of repression and alienation, told by magical girls at a jesus summer camp. I've played it a dozen times and would play it a dozen more.
